question: In adult medical intensive care units, does including a clinical pharmacist as a full member of rounding teams reduce the incidence of adverse drug events compared with rounds without a pharmacist? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: RESULTS The rate of preventable ordering ADEs decreased by 66% from 10.4 per 1000 patient-days (95% confidence interval [CI], 7-14) before the intervention to 3.5 (95% CI, 1-5; P<.001) after the intervention.
content.source_2: In a prospective ICU cohort, embedding a clinical pharmacist on daily ward rounds did not change the incidence of preventable ordering ADEs, which was 9.9 per 1000 patient-days before implementation and 10.1 afterward (adjusted rate ratio, 1.02; 95% CI, 0.78–1.33; P=.84).
content.source_3: CONCLUSIONS The presence of a pharmacist on rounds as a full member of the patient care team in a medical ICU was associated with a substantially lower rate of ADEs caused by prescribing errors.
content.source_4: A stepped-wedge multicenter evaluation reported that integrating pharmacists into rounding teams did not reduce ADEs; post-implementation incidence was 10.7 versus 10.5 per 1000 patient-days pre-implementation (difference, 0.2; 95% CI, −2.1 to 2.5; P=.87) after adjusting for case mix and census.
